questions.text: A 12-year girl is brought to the OPD by her mother. She is concerned that she is shorter than her peers. On examination there is ptosis on the right side, shield like chest and a webbed neck. On evaluation, which of the following would you expect to find? (NEET PG 2021 )

options.label: A
options.text: Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus

options.label: C
options.text: Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly with altered echotexture

questions.correct_answer: A. Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Turner Syndrome:
  • • Turner Syndrome:
  • • Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder affecting females, characterized by the absence of all or part of one X chromosome (45,XO). It presents with several distinct clinical features.
  • • Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder affecting females, characterized by the absence of all or part of one X chromosome (45,XO).
  • • It presents with several distinct clinical features.
  • • Clinical Features of Turner Syndrome:
  • • Clinical Features of Turner Syndrome:
  • • Short stature : Typically shorter than peers, often the first noticeable symptom. Primary amenorrhea : Due to streak gonads (non-functioning ovaries). Shield-like chest : Broad chest with widely spaced nipples. Webbed neck : Excess skin folds running from the tops of the shoulders to the sides of the neck. Ptosis : Drooping of the upper eyelid, can be unilateral or bilateral. Cardiac defects : Commonly coarctation of the aorta, though ventricular septal defects (VSD) can also occur but are less common. Renal anomalies : Such as horseshoe kidney or a single kidney. Other features : Low-set ears, high-arched palate, arms that turn outward at the elbows, narrow and turned-up fingernails and toenails, low hairline at the back of the head, receding or small lower jaw.

  • • Short stature
  • • Primary amenorrhea : Due to streak gonads (non-functioning ovaries).

  • • Webbed neck

  • • Ptosis

  • • Cardiac defects
  • • Renal anomalies : Such as horseshoe kidney or a single kidney.
  • • Renal anomalies
  • • Other features : Low-set ears, high-arched palate, arms that turn outward at the elbows, narrow and turned-up fingernails and toenails, low hairline at the back of the head, receding or small lower jaw.
  • • Other features
  • • Ultrasound Findings:
  • • Ultrasound Findings:
  • • The presence of streak ovaries (underdeveloped ovaries) and a small uterus are typical findings in Turner syndrome, leading to primary amenorrhea and infertility.
  • • The presence of streak ovaries (underdeveloped ovaries) and a small uterus are typical findings in Turner syndrome, leading to primary amenorrhea and infertility.
  • • streak ovaries
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. ECHO shows VSD: While Turner syndrome can involve congenital heart defects, the most common cardiac anomalies are coarctation of the aorta and bicuspid aortic valve, not ventricular septal defect (VSD).
  • • Option B. ECHO shows VSD:
  • • Option C. Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly with altered echotexture: This is not typically associated with Turner syndrome. Hepatomegaly might suggest liver disease or metabolic disorders, which are not characteristic of Turner syndrome.
  • • Option C. Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly with altered echotexture:
  • • Option D. Ultrasound showing single kidney: Renal anomalies can occur in Turner syndrome, such as a horseshoe kidney or a single kidney, but the primary findings expected include streak ovaries and a small uterus which are more specific for Turner syndrome.
  • • Option D. Ultrasound showing single kidney:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45,XO genotype, primary amenorrhea, short stature, and distinctive physical features such as a webbed neck and shield-like chest. Ultrasound typically shows streak ovaries and a small uterus.

questions.text: Most common site of genital TB is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fallopian tube

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Genital tuberculosis (TB) primarily affects the female reproductive system, with the fallopian tubes being the most common site of infection. Tuberculous salpingitis can lead to various complications, including:
  • • Endosalpingitis or Exosalpingitis: Inflammation inside or around the fallopian tubes. Beading of the tube: Formation of small nodular masses or swellings along the tube. Constriction of the tube: Narrowing of the tube, which can obstruct the passage of the ovum. Hydrosalpinx: Accumulation of fluid in the fallopian tube, often due to obstruction caused by TB.
  • • Endosalpingitis or Exosalpingitis: Inflammation inside or around the fallopian tubes.
  • • Beading of the tube: Formation of small nodular masses or swellings along the tube.
  • • Constriction of the tube: Narrowing of the tube, which can obstruct the passage of the ovum.
  • • Hydrosalpinx: Accumulation of fluid in the fallopian tube, often due to obstruction caused by TB.
  • • These complications can significantly impact fertility, making infertility a common issue in women with genital TB.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Sites of Genital TB:
  • • Option A. Cervix: Less commonly affected.
  • • Option A. Cervix:
  • • Option B. Endometrium: Can be involved, but not as frequently as the fallopian tubes.
  • • Option B. Endometrium:
  • • Option D. Ovary: Also less commonly affected compared to the fallopian tubes.
  • • Option D. Ovary:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fallopian tube is the most common site of genital tuberculosis, leading to significant complications such as salpingitis, hydrosalpinx, and infertility.

questions.text: A pregnant lady with a history of recurrent abortions is now diagnosed to have antiphospholipid syndrome. What would be the best mode of treatment for her? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aspirin + heparin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Aspirin + heparin:
  • • Aspirin + heparin:
  • • Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by recurrent pregnancy loss, thrombosis, and the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies. The primary cause of pregnancy loss in APS is believed to be due to inhibition of trophoblast function and differentiation, which leads to placental dysfunction. The best management approach for pregnant women with APS includes: Low dose aspirin : Initiated as soon as pregnancy is confirmed. Aspirin helps by preventing platelet aggregation and improving blood flow to the placenta. Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) : Started once fetal cardiac activity is detected. LMWH helps prevent blood clot formation, thus reducing the risk of thrombosis and improving pregnancy outcomes.
  • • Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by recurrent pregnancy loss, thrombosis, and the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies.
  • • The primary cause of pregnancy loss in APS is believed to be due to inhibition of trophoblast function and differentiation, which leads to placental dysfunction.
  • • The best management approach for pregnant women with APS includes: Low dose aspirin : Initiated as soon as pregnancy is confirmed. Aspirin helps by preventing platelet aggregation and improving blood flow to the placenta. Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) : Started once fetal cardiac activity is detected. LMWH helps prevent blood clot formation, thus reducing the risk of thrombosis and improving pregnancy outcomes.
  • • Low dose aspirin : Initiated as soon as pregnancy is confirmed. Aspirin helps by preventing platelet aggregation and improving blood flow to the placenta. Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) : Started once fetal cardiac activity is detected. LMWH helps prevent blood clot formation, thus reducing the risk of thrombosis and improving pregnancy outcomes.
  • • Low dose aspirin : Initiated as soon as pregnancy is confirmed. Aspirin helps by preventing platelet aggregation and improving blood flow to the placenta.
  • • Low dose aspirin
  • • Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) : Started once fetal cardiac activity is detected. LMWH helps prevent blood clot formation, thus reducing the risk of thrombosis and improving pregnancy outcomes.
  • • Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Aspirin only: While low-dose aspirin is beneficial, it is not sufficient alone for the prevention of complications in APS. The addition of heparin provides better protection against thrombosis and pregnancy loss.
  • • Option A. Aspirin only:
  • • Option C. Aspirin + heparin + steroids : Steroids are not routinely used in the management of APS during pregnancy due to their potential side effects and lack of evidence showing added benefit in preventing pregnancy loss when combined with aspirin and heparin.
  • • Option C. Aspirin + heparin +
  • • steroids
  • • Option D. Aspirin + steroids: Similar to the previous option, steroids are not recommended as part of the standard management for APS in pregnancy. The combination of aspirin and heparin is the preferred treatment.
  • • Option D. Aspirin + steroids:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best management for pregnant women with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) to prevent recurrent pregnancy loss includes low-dose aspirin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).

questions.text: Testosterone helps in the development of various organs in the fetus. Which of the following stimulates its production? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) HCG from placenta

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • HCG from placenta : HCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) from the placenta stimulates the production of testosterone in the male fetus. HCG released from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus. Later by the eighth week of gestation, fetal pituitary LH (luteinizing hormone) stimulates the Leydig cells of the testes to produce testosterone. Sex differentiation of the embryo depends on the Y chromosome, which contains the testis-determining gene called the SRY (sex-determining region on Y) gene. In a genetically male embryo (46, XY), the gonad is converted into testis under the influence of this gene. Female development (Mullerian ducts) occurs in the absence of this gene.
  • • HCG from placenta : HCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) from the placenta stimulates the production of testosterone in the male fetus. HCG released from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus. Later by the eighth week of gestation, fetal pituitary LH (luteinizing hormone) stimulates the Leydig cells of the testes to produce testosterone. Sex differentiation of the embryo depends on the Y chromosome, which contains the testis-determining gene called the SRY (sex-determining region on Y) gene. In a genetically male embryo (46, XY), the gonad is converted into testis under the influence of this gene. Female development (Mullerian ducts) occurs in the absence of this gene.
  • • HCG from placenta

HCG released from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus. Later by the eighth week of gestation, fetal pituitary LH (luteinizing hormone) stimulates the Leydig cells of the testes to produce testosterone. Sex differentiation of the embryo depends on the Y chromosome, which contains the testis-determining gene called the SRY (sex-determining region on Y) gene. In a genetically male embryo (46, XY), the gonad is converted into testis under the influence of this gene. Female development (Mullerian ducts) occurs in the absence of this gene.

  • • Later by the eighth week of gestation, fetal pituitary LH (luteinizing hormone) stimulates the Leydig cells of the testes to produce testosterone.
  • • Sex differentiation of the embryo depends on the Y chromosome, which contains the testis-determining gene called the SRY (sex-determining region on Y) gene.
  • • In a genetically male embryo (46, XY), the gonad is converted into testis under the influence of this gene.
  • • Female development (Mullerian ducts) occurs in the absence of this gene.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. LH from maternal pituitary : Maternal LH does not play a role in fetal testosterone production. The fetal pituitary gland, not the maternal pituitary, influences testosterone production later in gestation.
  • • Option A. LH from maternal pituitary
  • • Option C. Inhibin from corpus luteum : Inhibin is involved in the regulation of FSH and does not stimulate testosterone production. It primarily acts to provide feedback inhibition to the anterior pituitary gland to control FSH levels.
  • • Option C. Inhibin from corpus luteum
  • • Option D. GnRH from fetal hypothalamus : GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone) from the fetal hypothalamus plays a role in stimulating the fetal pituitary to release LH and FSH, but it is not the initial trigger for testosterone production in the fetus.
  • • Option D. GnRH from fetal hypothalamus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HCG from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus.

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant lady presents with fever and is put on antibiotics. Fever is still not brought under control. On further investigation, she is diagnosed to have septic pelvic thrombophlebitis. Which among the following is the next course of treatment for her? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Antibiotics + Heparin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Antibiotics + heparin:
  • • Antibiotics + heparin:
  • • Septic pelvic thrombophlebitis (SPT) is a rare postpartum infective complication characterized by persistent high-grade fever despite broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy. It typically occurs after delivery or abortion and is often seen in women with risk factors like cesarean section, prolonged labor, or pelvic infection.
  • • The fever in SPT is caused by a septic thrombus in the pelvic veins—most commonly the ovarian vein—that harbors bacteria and incites a sustained inflammatory response. Since antibiotics alone cannot fully penetrate the infected thrombus, the addition of anticoagulation (usually low molecular weight heparin) is essential. Heparin helps in lysing the thrombus, preventing further propagation and improving antibiotic penetration.
  • • Clinical improvement is usually seen within 48–72 hours of initiating combined therapy with antibiotics and heparin.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Stop antibiotics and start heparin : Incorrect because infection is still present—antibiotics are needed to control the infective component. Stopping antibiotics would worsen sepsis.
  • • Option A. Stop antibiotics and start heparin
  • • Option C. Surgical embolectomy: Too invasive and not first-line. Reserved for rare cases with septic emboli or failure to respond to medical management.
  • • Option C. Surgical embolectomy:
  • • Option D. Hysterectomy: Not indicated unless there’s uncontrolled pelvic infection not responding to medical therapy or associated endomyometritis with uterine necrosis. SPT is usually confined to pelvic veins, not requiring removal of the uterus.
  • • Option D. Hysterectomy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best management for pregnant women with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) to prevent recurrent pregnancy loss includes low-dose aspirin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 2951, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 2951, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding perimortem cesarean section? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Upper segment cesarean section

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • An upper segment cesarean section is performed during a perimortem cesarean section (PMCS). PMCS is an emergency cesarean delivery of a woman who is expected to die within the next few moments or has just died.
  • • Key points about PMCS:
  • • Timing : According to the AHA 2020 Guidelines for CPR, perimortem cesarean should be considered if there is no return of spontaneous circulation within 5 minutes in a pregnant woman who has experienced total cardiopulmonary arrest. Purpose : The goal of PMCS is to improve maternal and fetal outcomes by relieving the compression of the inferior vena cava (IVC) by the gravid uterus, which enhances venous return and diaphragmatic displacement. This, in turn, improves respiratory dynamics and resuscitative efforts. Fetal Outcome : The infant has a higher chance of survival if PMCS is performed within 10 minutes of maternal death. Surgical Technique : A classical upper-segment cesarean section with a vertical uterine incision is performed. Location : PMCS does not need to be done in the operating theatre (OT); it can be done wherever the patient is located to expedite the process.
  • • Timing : According to the AHA 2020 Guidelines for CPR, perimortem cesarean should be considered if there is no return of spontaneous circulation within 5 minutes in a pregnant woman who has experienced total cardiopulmonary arrest.
  • • Timing
  • • Purpose : The goal of PMCS is to improve maternal and fetal outcomes by relieving the compression of the inferior vena cava (IVC) by the gravid uterus, which enhances venous return and diaphragmatic displacement. This, in turn, improves respiratory dynamics and resuscitative efforts.
  • • Purpose
  • • Fetal Outcome : The infant has a higher chance of survival if PMCS is performed within 10 minutes of maternal death.
  • • Fetal Outcome
  • • Surgical Technique : A classical upper-segment cesarean section with a vertical uterine incision is performed.
  • • Surgical Technique
  • • Location : PMCS does not need to be done in the operating theatre (OT); it can be done wherever the patient is located to expedite the process.
  • • Location
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. LSCS : Lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) is not typically used in PMCS.
  • • Option A. LSCS
  • • Option B. Pfannenstiel incision : This is a horizontal incision typically used in elective cesarean sections, not in emergency PMCS.
  • • Option B. Pfannenstiel incision
  • • Option D. Done in OT : PMCS does not need to be performed in the operating theatre; it can be done immediately at the site of the patient to save time.
  • • Option D. Done in OT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Perimortem cesarean section (PMCS) involves performing a classical upper-segment cesarean section with a vertical uterine incision in an emergency situation to improve maternal and fetal outcomes.

questions.text: Identify the maternal condition that can lead to the findings in the baby as shown below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pre-gestational diabetes

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The image shows a condition known as mermaid syndrome or sirenomelia, which is a rare congenital deformity characterized by the fusion of the lower limbs. This condition is characteristically associated with overt (pre-gestational) diabetes mellitus.
  • • Key Points:
  • • Key Points:
  • • Sirenomelia (mermaid syndrome) is strongly linked to maternal pre-gestational diabetes. Overt diabetes mellitus during pregnancy is known to cause various congenital anomalies, with cardiac anomalies being the most common, specifically ventricular septal defects (VSD).
  • • Sirenomelia (mermaid syndrome) is strongly linked to maternal pre-gestational diabetes.
  • • Overt diabetes mellitus during pregnancy is known to cause various congenital anomalies, with cardiac anomalies being the most common, specifically ventricular septal defects (VSD).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Gestational diabetes mellitus: Gestational diabetes typically occurs later in pregnancy and does not usually cause congenital anomalies, as organogenesis is largely complete by the time gestational diabetes is diagnosed.
  • • Option B. Gestational diabetes mellitus:
  • • Option C. Effect of valproate: Valproate exposure during pregnancy is associated with neural tube defects, facial anomalies (such as cleft lip and palate), and cardiac anomalies, but not sirenomelia.
  • • Option C. Effect of valproate:
  • • Option D. Hypertensive on ACE inhibitors: ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers reduce fetal renal perfusion, leading to conditions such as oligohydramnios and subsequent pulmonary hypoplasia, but they do not cause sirenomelia.
  • • Option D. Hypertensive on ACE inhibitors:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pre-gestational diabetes is associated with an increased risk of congenital anomalies, including mermaid syndrome (sirenomelia), characterized by the fusion of lower limbs.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 384, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 384, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

Reason for previous cesarean : Conditions like cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) or other recurrent indications may reduce the likelihood of a successful TOLAC and increase the risk of complications. questions.text: A young girl presented with delayed puberty. On examination, secondary sexual characters were absent, the nipples were widely spaced, and she was short in height. The most likely karyotype would be? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 45XO

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical features described in the question are characteristic of Turner syndrome, which is caused by the presence of only one X chromosome (45XO karyotype). The key features of Turner syndrome include:
  • • Delayed puberty and absence of secondary sexual characteristics: Due to ovarian dysgenesis or streak ovaries, which lead to primary ovarian insufficiency. Short stature: Almost all girls with Turner syndrome are short. Widely spaced nipples and shield-like chest: These are typical physical features of Turner syndrome. Webbed neck (common feature).
  • • Delayed puberty and absence of secondary sexual characteristics: Due to ovarian dysgenesis or streak ovaries, which lead to primary ovarian insufficiency.
  • • Short stature: Almost all girls with Turner syndrome are short.
  • • Widely spaced nipples and shield-like chest: These are typical physical features of Turner syndrome.
  • • Webbed neck (common feature).
  • • Note - 46XXX: This karyotype, also known as triple X syndrome, typically presents with taller than average stature and normal sexual development, which does not match the described clinical features.
  • • Note

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The karyotype 45XO is associated with Turner syndrome, which is characterized by delayed puberty, absence of secondary sexual characteristics, short stature, widely spaced nipples, and other distinctive physical features.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common presentation of postpartum nerve injury? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Foot drop

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The most common postpartum nerve injury is an injury to the peroneal nerve, which results in foot drop. This type of injury often occurs during deliveries where the lithotomy position is used for an extended period. The lithotomy position can cause prolonged pressure on the peroneal nerve, which is located near the fibular head, leading to nerve damage.
  • • Key Points:
  • • Key Points:
  • • Peroneal nerve injury: The peroneal nerve is susceptible to compression, especially when the legs are positioned in stirrups for prolonged periods, as is common in the lithotomy position during childbirth. Foot drop: This condition is characterized by an inability to dorsiflex the foot, leading to a dragging foot while walking. Symptoms: Patients may present with weakness in lifting the front part of the foot and toes, a high-stepping gait to prevent the foot from dragging, and numbness or tingling over the top of the foot and the outer part of the upper leg.
  • • Peroneal nerve injury: The peroneal nerve is susceptible to compression, especially when the legs are positioned in stirrups for prolonged periods, as is common in the lithotomy position during childbirth.

  • • Other Options:

  • • Option A. Facial palsy
  • • Option B. Wrist drop : This condition results from a radial nerve injury and is not a common presentation of postpartum nerve injuries.
  • • Option B. Wrist drop
  • • Option D. Claw hand : This is associated with ulnar nerve injury and is also not a common presentation of postpartum nerve injuries.

questions.text: Arrange the following in sequence? (INICET NOV 2022) Crowning Engagement Restitution External rotation
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) B, A, C, D

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The sequence of cardinal movements in the mechanism of labor is a series of positions and motions that the fetus goes through as it navigates through the birth canal. These movements are:
  • • Engagement : This is when the fetal head enters the pelvic inlet and the widest part of the head has passed through the pelvic brim. Descent : The downward movement of the fetal head within the pelvic inlet. Flexion : The fetal head bends so the chin is brought closer to the chest, presenting the smallest diameter to the birth canal. Internal Rotation : The fetal head rotates to align with the maternal pelvis. Extension : The fetal head extends as it passes under the symphysis pubis, followed by the crowning (the fetal head remains visible at the vulva without slipping back). Crowning : The fetal head is visible at the vulva without slipping back. Restitution : The fetal head rotates to the position it was in when it engaged in the pelvis. External Rotation : The fetal shoulders rotate to align with the head. Expulsion of the rest of the body : The remainder of the fetal body is delivered.
  • • Engagement : This is when the fetal head enters the pelvic inlet and the widest part of the head has passed through the pelvic brim.
  • • Engagement
  • • Descent : The downward movement of the fetal head within the pelvic inlet.
  • • Descent
  • • Flexion : The fetal head bends so the chin is brought closer to the chest, presenting the smallest diameter to the birth canal.
  • • Flexion
  • • Internal Rotation : The fetal head rotates to align with the maternal pelvis.
  • • Internal Rotation
  • • Extension : The fetal head extends as it passes under the symphysis pubis, followed by the crowning (the fetal head remains visible at the vulva without slipping back).
  • • Extension
  • • Crowning : The fetal head is visible at the vulva without slipping back.
  • • Crowning
  • • Restitution : The fetal head rotates to the position it was in when it engaged in the pelvis.
  • • Restitution
  • • External Rotation : The fetal shoulders rotate to align with the head.
  • • External Rotation
  • • Expulsion of the rest of the body : The remainder of the fetal body is delivered.
  • • Expulsion of the rest of the body
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B. B, A, D, C : This sequence incorrectly places external rotation before restitution.
  • • Option B. B, A, D, C
  • • Option C. B, C, A, D : This sequence incorrectly places restitution before crowning.
  • • Option C. B, C, A, D
  • • Option D. B, D, A, C : This sequence incorrectly places external rotation before crowning and restitution.
  • • Option D. B, D, A, C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cardinal movements in the mechanism of labor occur in the following sequence: engagement, descent, flexion, internal rotation, extension (preceded by crowning), restitution, external rotation, and expulsion of the rest of the body.

questions.text: What is altered in thyroid profile throughout pregnancy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Total T3 level

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • During pregnancy, the thyroid profile undergoes several changes due to physiological adaptations. One significant change is the increase in total T3 and T4 levels. This occurs because of the elevated levels of thyroid-binding globulin (TBG), which increases the amount of bound thyroid hormones. Despite this increase, the levels of free T3 and free T4 remain relatively unchanged.
  • • Key Points:
  • • Key Points:
  • • Thyroid-binding globulin (TBG): The production of TBG increases during pregnancy due to elevated estrogen levels. This leads to higher levels of total T3 and total T4. Free T3 and Free T4: Despite the increase in total hormone levels, the free (unbound) hormone levels remain relatively stable. This is why free T3 and free T4 are preferred for thyroid function testing during pregnancy. TSH: The levels of TSH may decrease slightly in the first trimester due to the thyrotropic effects of hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin), but they generally stabilize in the second and third trimesters. Iodine requirement: Pregnancy increases the body's requirement for iodine by about 50%, due to increased renal clearance and fetal iodine needs.
  • • Thyroid-binding globulin (TBG): The production of TBG increases during pregnancy due to elevated estrogen levels. This leads to higher levels of total T3 and total T4.
  • • Thyroid-binding globulin (TBG):
  • • Free T3 and Free T4: Despite the increase in total hormone levels, the free (unbound) hormone levels remain relatively stable. This is why free T3 and free T4 are preferred for thyroid function testing during pregnancy.
  • • Free T3 and Free T4:
  • • TSH: The levels of TSH may decrease slightly in the first trimester due to the thyrotropic effects of hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin), but they generally stabilize in the second and third trimesters.
  • • TSH:
  • • Iodine requirement: Pregnancy increases the body's requirement for iodine by about 50%, due to increased renal clearance and fetal iodine needs.
  • • Iodine requirement:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Free T3 level : This remains relatively unchanged during pregnancy.
  • • Option A. Free T3 level
  • • Option B. Free T4 level : This also remains relatively unchanged during pregnancy.
  • • Option B. Free T4 level
  • • Option D. TSH level : While TSH levels can decrease slightly in the first trimester, they typically stabilize throughout the rest of the pregnancy.
  • • Option D. TSH level

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In pregnancy, total T3 and T4 levels increase due to elevated thyroid-binding globulin, while free T3 and T4 levels remain unchanged.

questions.text: A 35-year woman is a chronic hypertensive. She visits the clinic for preconception counseling. Which of the following anti-hypertensives need to be stopped prior to conception? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) ACE inhibitors

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • ACE Inhibitors in Pregnancy:
  • • ACE Inhibitors in Pregnancy:
  • • ACE inhibitors are contraindicated during pregnancy due to their association with significant fetal complications. They can cause oligohydramnios, fetal growth restriction, renal dysgenesis, and even fetal death. Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARBs) are also contraindicated for similar reasons. It is essential for women on these medications to discontinue them prior to conception and switch to safer alternatives.

  • • It is essential for women on these medications to discontinue them prior to conception and switch to safer alternatives.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Calcium channel blockers: These are generally considered safe during pregnancy and do not need to be discontinued.
  • • Option A. Calcium channel blockers:
  • • Option B. Alpha methyl dopa: This is a safe and commonly used antihypertensive during pregnancy.
  • • Option B. Alpha methyl dopa:
  • • Option D. Labetalol: Labetalol is another safe option during pregnancy and is frequently used for managing hypertension in pregnant women.
  • • Option D. Labetalol:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin Receptor Blockers are contraindicated during pregnancy and should be discontinued prior to conception.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is evaluated for primary infertility. Semen analysis shows azoospermia. A testicular biopsy is done and the image is shown below. The shown finding is consistent with? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sertoli cell only syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Sertoli cell only syndrome : The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Sertoli cell-only syndrome. Patients with Sertoli cell-only syndrome typically present between the ages of 20 and 40 years with primary infertility. Diagnosis is confirmed through testicular biopsy. The histopathology of the biopsy specimen typically shows seminiferous tubules populated by only Sertoli cells, with thickening of the tubular basement membrane and absence of germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.

questions.text: In screening for diabetes in pregnancy, the dose of oral glucose load given is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 75g

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • For screening and diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), the oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is commonly used. The standard protocol involves a 75-gram oral glucose load.
  • • Protocol for 75-gram OGTT:
  • • International Guidelines: According to the International Association of Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Groups (IADPSG):
  • • International Guidelines: According to the International Association of Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Groups (IADPSG):
  • • The test is performed after an overnight fast. A fasting blood sample is taken. The woman is then given a 75-gram oral glucose load. Blood samples are taken at 1 hour and 2 hours after the glucose load. Diagnostic thresholds: Fasting glucose ≥ 92 mg/dL 1-hour glucose ≥ 180 mg/dL 2-hour glucose ≥ 153 mg/dL
  • • The test is performed after an overnight fast.
  • • A fasting blood sample is taken.
  • • The woman is then given a 75-gram oral glucose load.
  • • Blood samples are taken at 1 hour and 2 hours after the glucose load.
  • • Diagnostic thresholds: Fasting glucose ≥ 92 mg/dL 1-hour glucose ≥ 180 mg/dL 2-hour glucose ≥ 153 mg/dL
  • • Fasting glucose ≥ 92 mg/dL 1-hour glucose ≥ 180 mg/dL 2-hour glucose ≥ 153 mg/dL
  • • Fasting glucose ≥ 92 mg/dL
  • • 1-hour glucose ≥ 180 mg/dL
  • • 2-hour glucose ≥ 153 mg/dL
  • • A diagnosis of GDM is made if any one of these values is met or exceeded.
  • • DIPSI Criteria (India):
  • • DIPSI Criteria (India):
  • • This method can be used irrespective of the prandial state (whether the woman is fasting or not).
  • • A 75-gram oral glucose load is given. A blood sample is taken 2 hours later. A 2-hour plasma glucose value ≥ 140 mg/dL indicates GDM.
  • • A 75-gram oral glucose load is given.
  • • A blood sample is taken 2 hours later.
  • • A 2-hour plasma glucose value ≥ 140 mg/dL indicates GDM.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 50g : Used in the 50-gram glucose challenge test, which is a preliminary screening test, but not diagnostic.
  • • Option A. 50g
  • • Option C. 100g : Used in the 3-hour OGTT, which is less commonly used now compared to the 75-gram test.
  • • Option C. 100g
  • • Option D. 150g : Not used for GDM screening or diagnosis.
  • • Option D. 150g
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The current standard for screening and diagnosing gestational diabetes mellitus is the 75-gram oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT).

questions.text: Amsel criteria is used for? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bacterial vaginosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Amsel's criteria are used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis (BV). The diagnosis requires at least three out of the following four criteria to be present:
  • • Homogeneous, thin, white discharge that smoothly coats the vaginal walls. Clue cells on microscopy: Vaginal epithelial cells that appear stippled with bacteria. Positive whiff test: A fishy odor is released when a solution of 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) is added to a sample of the vaginal discharge. Vaginal pH > 4.5: An elevated pH is indicative of BV.
  • • Homogeneous, thin, white discharge that smoothly coats the vaginal walls.
  • • Clue cells on microscopy: Vaginal epithelial cells that appear stippled with bacteria.
  • • Positive whiff test: A fishy odor is released when a solution of 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) is added to a sample of the vaginal discharge.
  • • Vaginal pH > 4.5: An elevated pH is indicative of BV.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Candidiasis: Diagnosed primarily by clinical presentation and microscopic identification of yeast cells or pseudo hyphae.
  • • Option B. Candidiasis:
  • • Option C. Cervicitis: Diagnosed based on clinical findings and specific laboratory tests for pathogens like Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
  • • Option C. Cervicitis:
  • • Option D. Trichomoniasis: Diagnosed by identifying the flagellated protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis on a wet mount microscopy or by specific antigen tests.
  • • Option D. Trichomoniasis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amsel criteria are specifically used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis, requiring the presence of at least three out of four specific clinical and laboratory findings.

questions.text: A woman with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Which of the following is true? (NEET PF 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance

options.label: B
options.text: Small blood vessels are most radioresistant

options.label: C
options.text: Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant

questions.correct_answer: A. Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This statement refers to the Inverse Square Law, which states that the intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source. This means that as the distance from the radiation source increases, the intensity of the radiation decreases exponentially. This law is fundamental in radiation physics and is crucial for understanding radiation exposure and protection.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Small blood vessels are most radioresistant: This is incorrect. Larger vessels are more radioresistant compared to smaller ones. The endothelial cells lining small vessels are more susceptible to radiation damage due to their relatively higher rate of proliferation.
  • • Option B. Small blood vessels are most radioresistant:
  • • Option C. Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant: This is incorrect. Rapidly proliferating cells are the most radiosensitive. Cells that are dividing quickly, such as those in the gastrointestinal tract, bone marrow, and reproductive tissues, are more susceptible to radiation damage because radiation primarily affects DNA during cell division.
  • • Option C. Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant:
  • • Option D. Small bowel is most radioresistant: This is incorrect. The gastrointestinal (GI) tract, including the small bowel, is among the most radiosensitive organ systems in the body. This high radiosensitivity is due to the rapid turnover of the epithelial cells lining the GI tract.
  • • Option D. Small bowel is most radioresistant:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source, as described by the Inverse Square Law.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 610, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 610, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: A 21-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal OPD. Her school going nephew who lives in the same house has contracted varicella. A blood sample is taken for Antibodies against varicella. The report is negative. What does this signify? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Susceptible to chicken pox

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Chickenpox in Pregnancy:
  • • Chickenpox in Pregnancy:
  • • Pregnant women with uncertain or no previous history of chickenpox, who have been exposed to the infection, should have a blood test to determine their immunity to Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV). A negative antibody test indicates that the woman is not immune to VZV and is susceptible to chickenpox. If a pregnant woman is not immune and has had significant exposure, she is at risk of developing chickenpox and should be administered varicella-zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG). VZIG is effective up to 10 days after contact. Symptomatic treatment of chickenpox in pregnancy includes: Oral Acyclovir if within 24 hours of the onset of the rash and if the gestational age is greater than 20 weeks. Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox. VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once chickenpox has started. Women who develop chickenpox in pregnancy should be referred to a fetal medicine specialist at 16–20 weeks or 5 weeks after infection to look for congenital varicella syndrome. If the infection occurs in the last 4 weeks of pregnancy, there is a risk of varicella infection in the newborn. Planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.
  • • Pregnant women with uncertain or no previous history of chickenpox, who have been exposed to the infection, should have a blood test to determine their immunity to Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV).
  • • A negative antibody test indicates that the woman is not immune to VZV and is susceptible to chickenpox.
  • • If a pregnant woman is not immune and has had significant exposure, she is at risk of developing chickenpox and should be administered varicella-zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG).
  • • VZIG is effective up to 10 days after contact.
  • • Symptomatic treatment of chickenpox in pregnancy includes: Oral Acyclovir if within 24 hours of the onset of the rash and if the gestational age is greater than 20 weeks. Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • • Oral Acyclovir if within 24 hours of the onset of the rash and if the gestational age is greater than 20 weeks. Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • • Oral Acyclovir if within 24 hours of the onset of the rash and if the gestational age is greater than 20 weeks.
  • • Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • • VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once chickenpox has started.
  • • Women who develop chickenpox in pregnancy should be referred to a fetal medicine specialist at 16–20 weeks or 5 weeks after infection to look for congenital varicella syndrome.
  • • If the infection occurs in the last 4 weeks of pregnancy, there is a risk of varicella infection in the newborn. Planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Immune to chickenpox: A negative antibody test does not signify immunity; it signifies susceptibility.
  • • Option B. Immune to chickenpox:
  • • Option C. Susceptible to zoster: Varicella-zoster virus causes both chickenpox (primary infection) and shingles (reactivation). A negative test for varicella antibodies indicates susceptibility to the primary infection (chickenpox), not to shingles.
  • • Option C. Susceptible to zoster:
  • • Option D. Immune to zoster: Immunity to zoster would imply prior exposure to the varicella-zoster virus, which is not indicated by a negative varicella antibody test.
  • • Option D. Immune to zoster:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A negative varicella antibody test in a pregnant woman indicates that she is susceptible to chickenpox and should receive VZIG if exposed.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 3085, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 3085, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presented at 7 weeks of gestation, unwilling to continue the pregnancy. What are the drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Misoprostol and Mifepristone

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Misoprostol and Mifepristone : The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone. Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy. Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue. Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.
  • • Misoprostol and Mifepristone : The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone. Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy. Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue. Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.
  • • Misoprostol and Mifepristone
  • • The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone. Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy. Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue. Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.
  • • The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone.
  • • Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy.
  • • Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue.
  • • Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Misoprostol and Medroxyprogesterone : Medroxyprogesterone is a synthetic progestin used in contraception and hormone replacement therapy but is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.
  • • Option A. Misoprostol and Medroxyprogesterone
  • • Option C. Mifepristone and Methotrexate : Methotrexate is a folate antagonist that can be used in combination with misoprostol for medical termination of pregnancy, especially in early gestations, but it is not the standard regimen compared to mifepristone and misoprostol.
  • • Option C. Mifepristone and Methotrexate
  • • Option D. Mifepristone and Medroxyprogesterone : Medroxyprogesterone is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.
  • • Option D. Mifepristone and Medroxyprogesterone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For medical termination of pregnancy at 7 weeks of gestation, the recommended drugs are mifepristone followed by misoprostol.

questions.text: A multiparous woman from a low socio-economic status whose husband is a truck driver is to be screened for cervical cancer. What is the best way? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pap smear

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cervical cancer screening is crucial for early detection and prevention. The Pap smear (Papanicolaou test) is the standard screening test for cervical cancer, particularly in resource-limited settings. It involves collecting cells from the cervix to detect precancerous or cancerous changes.
  • • Why Pap Smear?
  • • Accessibility: It is widely available and can be performed in low-resource settings. Cost-effective: It is a cost-effective method for cervical cancer screening. Proven efficacy: It has been proven to significantly reduce the incidence and mortality of cervical cancer through early detection and treatment of precancerous lesions.
  • • Accessibility: It is widely available and can be performed in low-resource settings.
  • • Cost-effective: It is a cost-effective method for cervical cancer screening.
  • • Proven efficacy: It has been proven to significantly reduce the incidence and mortality of cervical cancer through early detection and treatment of precancerous lesions.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. CA125 : This is a biomarker used in the screening and monitoring of ovarian cancer, not cervical cancer.
  • • Option A. CA125
  • • Option B. Laparoscopy : This is a surgical procedure used for diagnosis and treatment but not for routine screening.
  • • Option B. Laparoscopy
  • • Option C. TVS (Transvaginal Sonography): Primarily used for evaluating the uterus and ovaries, not suitable for cervical cancer screening.
  • • Option C. TVS (Transvaginal Sonography):
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The Pap smear is the best and most widely recommended screening test for cervical cancer, especially in low socio-economic and resource-limited settings.

questions.text: Identify the use of the instrument given below? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: B
options.text: ﻿﻿﻿For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) For tubal ligation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The instrument shown is a laparoscopic ring applicator, also known as a laparocator. It is specifically designed for tubal ligation procedures. The instrument is used to apply Falope rings (silastic bands) on the fallopian tubes, which effectively block the tubes and prevent pregnancy. The Falope rings are preloaded on the tip of the instrument and are released after grasping the fallopian tube, thereby occluding the lumen.
  • • The instrument shown is a laparoscopic ring applicator, also known as a laparocator. It is specifically designed for tubal ligation procedures. The instrument is used to apply Falope rings (silastic bands) on the fallopian tubes, which effectively block the tubes and prevent pregnancy. The Falope rings are preloaded on the tip of the instrument and are released after grasping the fallopian tube, thereby occluding the lumen.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy: This is incorrect. The instrument shown is not used for ligating the uterine artery. Instead, instruments like clamps or ligature carriers are typically used for this purpose during a hysterectomy.
  • • Option B. For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy:
  • • Option C. Ovarian cystectomy: This is incorrect. The instrument is not used for ovarian cystectomy, which involves the removal of cysts from the ovary. Instruments like scissors, graspers, and cautery devices are commonly used in ovarian cystectomy procedures.
  • • Option C. Ovarian cystectomy:
  • • Option D. Ectopic pregnancy: This is incorrect. While laparoscopic instruments are used in the surgical management of ectopic pregnancy, the specific instrument shown (laparoscopic ring applicator) is not used for this purpose. Instruments used for ectopic pregnancy surgery include laparoscopic graspers, scissors, and suction devices.
  • • Option D. Ectopic pregnancy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The laparoscopic ring applicator (laparocator) is used for applying Falope rings during tubal ligation procedures.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not included in the criteria for neurofibromatosis 1? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: C
options.text: Dysplasia of the sphenoidal and tibial bone

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acoustic neuromas

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acoustic neuromas are not a diagnostic criterion for Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1); they are typically associated with Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2). The diagnostic criteria for NF1 include the presence of café-au-lait macules, axillary or inguinal freckling, Lisch nodules, neurofibromas, sphenoid dysplasia, optic gliomas, and a first-degree relative with NF1.

questions.text: The following are correct regarding normal placenta, except: (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Placenta weight at term is 470 g

options.label: C
options.text: Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

questions.correct_answer: C. Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The statement in option C is incorrect regarding the normal placenta.
  • • Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present: In a normal placenta, the umbilical cord typically contains three vessels (two arteries and one vein), not two. The presence of extraplacental membranes (membranes extending beyond the placental margins) is not a feature of a normal placenta; it is rather an abnormal finding if present.
  • • Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Placenta weight at term is 470 g: This is correct. The average weight of a term placenta is around 500 grams, but it can range from approximately 450 to 700 grams. The option provides a reasonable estimate.
  • • Option A. Placenta weight at term is 470 g:
  • • Option B. Round-oval with 22 cm diameter: This is partially correct. The normal placenta is indeed round to oval, but the average diameter is about 15-20 cm, not 22 cm. The provided diameter exceeds the typical range.
  • • Option B. Round-oval with 22 cm diameter:
  • • Option D. Central thickness > 2.5 cm: This is correct. The normal thickness of the placenta at term is greater than 2.5 cm, commonly around 2.5 to 4 cm. A thickness greater than 2.5 cm falls within the normal range.
  • • Option D. Central thickness > 2.5 cm:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The normal placenta at term typically weighs around 500 grams, has a diameter of 15-20 cm, is 2.5 cm thick, and has a 3-vessel umbilical cord with a central insertion.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 245 Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 245 Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
